lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “ir”, “er”, and “ur” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say: “bird, nurse, tiger.” Students repeat and underline “ir,” “ur,” or “er.” Sort words into columns on the board and practise pronunciation.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about interesting animals and find key details such as what they eat and where they live.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Students skim the text and highlight 3 appearance features of animals. Then answer: “Where does it live?” and “What does it eat?”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn interesting facts about animals through guided reading.
supportStrategies: (Science) Show photos of animals mentioned. Ask: “What does it look like?” or “Why is it special?” Students describe using new adjectives.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
